qas.question: What type of annelids are very different from others?
What type of tissue takes up most of the body of a leech?

answers.text: connective tissue layer of the body wall

qas.question: How many coelomata do leeches have?
What lines the coelomata of leeches?
What do leeches use to move?

answers.text: suckers at their front and rear ends

qas.question: What type of annelids are very identical to others?

plausible_answers.text: connective tissue layer of the body wall

qas.question: What type of tissue eats most of the body of a leech?
How many brains do leeches have?
What lines the bones of leeches?

plausible_answers.text: suckers at their front and rear ends

qas.question: What do leeches use to fly?

context: However, <a0_0><b5_0>leeches and their closest relatives<b5_0/><a0_0/> have a body structure that is very uniform within the group but significantly different from that of other annelids, including other members of the Clitellata. In leeches there are no septa, the <a1_0><b6_0>connective tissue layer of the body wall<b6_0/><a1_0/> is so thick that it occupies much of the body, and the <a2_0><b7_0>two<b7_0/><a2_0/> coelomata are widely separated and run the length of the body. They function as the main blood vessels, although they are side-by-side rather than upper and lower. However, they are lined with <a3_0><b8_0>mesothelium<b8_0/><a3_0/>, like the coelomata and unlike the blood vessels of other annelids. Leeches generally use <a4_0><b9_0>suckers at their front and rear ends<b9_0/><a4_0/> to move like inchworms. The anus is on the upper surface of the pygidium.
